us from Lizzie herself - the first since her mother's death, I will copy it for you."Denbigh Nov. 12, 1878, My dear Janice, I am really sorry and ashamed your good kind letter has been so long unanswered, but I have been very ill and quite unable to think of writing letters. My health and spirits and all utterly broke down when I lost my own precious mother and it is only the last few weeks my strength and interest in things are returning. I know it was wrong to be so utterly prostrated but the draw upon my system beforehand had something to do with it, and mama was all the world to me. It felt as if the best part of my own life was gone and did not care in the least what became of me in future; my greatest wish was to go after her who had been my guide and companion all these years. I cannot give you any account of dear mama yet. I am not able to write particulars as the wave of sorrow comes on afresh every time. Suffice to say she passed away peacefully and sweetly with her dear loving hand in mine -  no pain, to trouble at the last. Oh! I cannot write more -- Thank you so much for your [unclear] I will value it highly. I want to write to Ella Williams some of [unclear] next days. I thank her for her baby's [unclear]. I think it very pretty. I spoke to uncle about what you asked me, and I think he has been writing

to Mr.Thomas, but I will enquire more particularly tomorrow, when he will most probably call. We are all very busy as i am giving my school up at Christmas. I think I have met with a very nice successor and I do hope she will get on. I shall be very sorry to part with my dear girls and governesses but Fairholme is not the place it was to me; it seems empty and desolate altho full. All my friends have been exceedingly knid and the dear ones in the home with me. Had it not been for their love and affection what should I have done? I wonder how hard it is that none of my relatives either in Utica or Chicago have written me one line of sympathy, in this the greatest sorrow of my life. Do they think that a school principal has no need of kindly words or sympathy. I often fancy some of my American friends have a strange idea of their cousin Lizzie. Now I must conclude this little rambling note. I am afraid if I do not write and send it tonight, I may put it off for another month or two. Hoping you are all quite well, and with dear love to all - your aff. cousin Lizzie Williams. All my Welsh relatives are well" It was about writing for the [unclear] that uncle N was to speak to Mr. Thomas. Mr.G. Cincinnati has not been asked to do anything or Mr. R.D.T.Knoxville. I meant to write to him. I had a kind reply from Mr. Chidlaw. He had been sick. He had been told that [unclear] had prepared it and thinks it is now in [unclear]. I must try to write again to him.

Monday P.M.
I am here alone. Mary had to have some change made in her Basque and did not get it till 11 1/2 A.M. today. We did not therefore go out till after 2 P.M. When we got through trading she went down town to make enquiries about the boat and I came here to make ready to start. After she left me I remembered that I had no key to get in. When were were at Mrs. Jones' Saturday I remembered that they said Mrs. J's key would fit both houses so I went there but found it only fitted the outside door. I hasened to 480 lest Mary might remember and get here first. But I found only a locked door. I ventured to ask help of the wife of the janitor. She tried all

her keys without success--then I thought I could climb in through one of the inside windows and by help of a chair and stool succeeded. The door is still locked and I have been here nearly two hours. It is not likely that we can start tonight as it is 6 P.M. now. I am expecting Mary every moment and write this to keep my nerves steady. I am enjoying my stay here and Mary is feeling better. If eating well is living well we belong to the aristocracy. We went over to Mary's church last evening. I was rather tired and did not go anywhere during the day. I thought of you a great deal and wished I knew how the S.S. class did and whether you took the boos &c. Did ma go to church? How do you like the monument?

433 W 84th New York
Jan. 13, 1879
Dear Sisters & Brother,
To Anna Everett--image
Did you get the letter I wrote Saturday? I have been looking all day for some line from you, when I ought rather to have been writing to you. How do you get along especially in the morning? Does George get up and have the house warm before it is very late. Is he careful to do as he promised me about eating less butter? We have not yet disposed of what I brought down but have been promised 24cts by that lady to whom Mary expected to sell it--but she said if we can do any better we are at liberty to do so. Mary has been out all day--she hopes to go with me this evening to see about the butter. She is quite busy and has hardly recovered from that fall. She promises to take me some day to see the place. I am very glad I came if only you get along well.

It is very pleasant here and mild, no snow, the sidewalks clean and dry. I wish very much Sarah and Anna were here - it would do them good, I am sure and they could not help enjoying it. I was in the other part of the flat yesterday and think them very pleasant. They say Mary can open the door from her room into the back room and make a fire there if she wishes. We mean to try and put those little dark rooms in better order.May has awoman come in to sweep once a week - we expect her tomorrow. Saturday evening I went with Mary to make calls and had a good time, last of all we called on Mrs. Jones and were invited to dinner Sunday - when we had chicken pie - very nice indeed it was and well appreciated. We also had fruit cake, some of Mrs. Jones' New year cake - very good. Saturday afternoon we went to look at cloaks - Mary fancies the [unclear]

they are worn a good deal - so are socks. If Sarah has a sock had it not better be rather large that she may put something under it. I hope to hear from you so that she can have it before Sunday. I have not heard from [unclear] yet but between Mary and me perhaps we could pay for the cloak if you need to use that butter check. Have you sent it that I may endorse it? Did you get the missing statement? so that we may know how much of that money ought to be William and Sarah's. Write to let us know what you want us to send . I have not been into the stores much and cannot tell prices. So if anything you ask for costs too much, we can wait for it till we are rich. Our things from home are very nice- the bread is so good , not hard or dry in the least - thank you very much for putting in two loaves, also the butter

you ought to [unclear] how sweet it is and all the other things are good as good can be. Mary is surprised to see meat pickles with such relish. i should not have been sorry  if I had brought more. Mrs. Joe is much obliged for the butter. She is taking the smallest roll also. We are to have sweet potatoes to supper. We got a quart for 6 cts Saturday night and had some to breakfast with fresh fried fish Sunday morning. I had to eat dinner alone today as Mary did not get in till 2 1/2 PM and it is now almost 6 and supper waits her appearance. Tomorrow we expect to go to [unclear] of a course of Historical lectures. Mary had two season tickets given her. I wish Sarah or Anna could go with her instead of me. don't you? I got a good pair of rubbers for 25 cts, shall I send you some? How are they at [unclear] and how are you all?

433, W34th st. New York Feb. 12 1899
My dear sisters, Anna's letter came this morning and another a few days before. I do not know how to excuse myself for my neglect in writing. I am feeling much better of my cold. Yesterday we went with Mrs. Jones to visit Miss. Mary Hogg. We had arranged to do so last Friday when we had a visit with her and her intended intended at Mrs. Jones and tho it rained yesterday we decided to go. We enjoyed ourselves very much and were not sorry. I am deciding also to ask Eddie . Am glad he is going to collect. Will you go up there or will he stop at home? Love to all from [unclear]

we went. Miss. Hogg expects to be married soon to a Mr. Sparks. He came there to tea yesterday and every one was very kind to us. Mary was anxious to get here for her office [unclear] so we sat down to tea before Mr. S came, but he was there before we left the table. Mary came home on the elevated rail road as she was in a hurry but Mrs. J and I took the street car and walked across from 2nd avenue. We got home first and I was quite frightened to find Mary had not come. Mrs. Jones went straight home and I came alone from 9th av. so I did not have her to consult. It was nearly half an hour before Mary came. I went to ask Mrs. [unclear] if she supposed there could have been any accident. She did

not think I need unclear for Mary, but I was very glad indeed when at last - she came - she had been hindered - We are trying to write to unclear Eddie by the same mail as? this. If he is like? to accept? that proposal we think it will be well all around. He would be a good deal of comfort for Sarah and get a good deal himself. I had a card from him this morning asking what I thought of it. He said he would have written a letter only he did not have a stamp - I will send him a little money and stamps. - unclear says he is doing nicely and is a good boy. - How is Sarah's cough? Mary wishes very much you and

She could come down here and stay awhile - she thinks she could cure Sara and you would find it do you? lots of good even if you? do not need curing - my hands are unclear well only I have a few unclear or? boils? My cold has gone somewhere? only my voice is not quite clear? yet. This is written in great haste - I will try to write again more patiently . Mary likes the cloak? and looks very nicely in it - the express carage? for bringing it back was only 40? unclear. We propose to have blanks printed to send as bills and receipts - I will send you a draft - and will be glad to know soon how you like it-

My dear Sisters, Mary has written a letter to Wm? and I will write to you. Owen intends stopping here and spending next Sabbath in the city on his way back to Phil. Mrs Jones invites him to occupy a bed at her house and Mary will enjoy having him here to unclear her. It has occured to me this morning that it will be just the chance for Anna to have nice company to come down. I have been here two months most  and it is time for a change. I am feeling much better now and since coming down and enjoy being more in society. Mary seems to have [[heaps?] of friends and unclear with her to call on patients remind me very much of dear father and mother going to see their friends - all are so glad to see her. I do think she is in her right place and God is blessing her. We were sadly grieved to hear of Maggie Evans'death - may the dear Heavenly Father comfort them all. We send our united love to you all - We had

I hope Anna will grow stronger too when she comes down; so you may look out for me Wednesday evening. I am very sorry not to give you time to write first but I waited another day the chance of coming with Owen would be bad- It will not do to leave Mary alone as she really need some on with her. She is kept quit unclear now, and it is pleasant being here, she is looking and feeling much better then when I first came down. We send today the unclear and the ribbon and a little brown?, If I can pack it. We would have sent oranges only those in the market have been frost-bitten and we are waiting for an other vessel to come in. unclear Mimmis, a friend and patient of Mary's has promised to look

out for some good ones for us. I am almost inclinded to get a barrel and send some to cousin Mary but do not like to venture. If we cannot get a good ones and so unclear I will try to bring a few of the beatt. I can find in my trunk enough to last till there are better ones in the market. That med.? was for you to take all around - we will send more. It is a new remedy - Mary and I find it does no good - it seems to put new life in the system. We can get  bread baked her now and if any thing should prevent my ging home this week you need not bake anything to sen with Owen. If you have a little dried corn to spare, it will be very acceptable.

but do not rob yourselves. We can get canned corn here very reasonably. We had not hoed any of what Mary brought but after I got your letter U cooked some and found it very nice. I do not need that thick unclear now that I have got over my cold, I put an extra wrapper on and find my unclear very comfortable mornings. Anna had better bring both unclear so she can wear one and Mary tho other and so she can finish them here if she likes - I could wear her old one at home. We went unclear evening and had a pleasant time - will tell you about it when I get home, It is very pleasant and mild here today just such weather as Anna (you both) would enjoy. Wish Sara could come too for a few weeks it would do her so much good. I have made a number of pleasant friends

March 20? 1899
My dear sisters Owen reached New York 9-15 a.m.  Saturday, Mary met him at the unclear and they they walked around some and visited Stewarts "Home for Women" before coming here. He had not slept much in the cars and so was pretty tired, and glad to rest and visit. After dinner he went down to call on Johny Owen in Watkin's? store, and frome there he went to the P.O. building and got back here a little after three,

Mary and I went with him to the Park and we had a pleasant time in the museum. Mary had to come home for her office hour while Owen and I went to call of Jennie Owen. We found the number and street without trouble and enjoyed our call. The house was built for Tweed and was very large and grand, they had a reception the evening beforre and had two beautiful baskets of flowers in the windows, which graced the table at the time of their company. Mrs. Lewis, Jennie's aunt gave me some of the flowers. Sunday Mary ook Oven to her church in the morning and in the afternoon we went to hear Dr. John Hall. We had a good forward seat

so that I could understand a little. Dr. H. seems about -60- a pleasant easy speaker. He used no notes - read his text from one of those parts of the scripture, like ours and during the first half of the time held the book in His hand as if referring often to the text. The chuch is the most beautiful I ever was in. We did not go to church in the evening as Owen felt tired. Mary went out to thry to find out about the trains for Phila , as Owen wanted to reach there by 9 a.m. today. When we went to Mrs. Jones and David had come home about 10 p.m., he said Owen had better start at midnight as it would not be sage for him to go at 8 o'clock alone through that part of

city, as he must do if he waited. So David went with him about 11 p.m. to see him safe to the cars. Mary is delighted with that saque. She wore it yesterday over my silk drss, and she looked very grand. If it is not too late I would like mine straight around the bottom, crossed through: about the same length or a little bit longer than hers is in the back -and two little square? pockets - longer than they are deep - with the border on three sides - they are to be sewed on - I wrote when I fist sent the worsted? but Mary did not quite like something I had in the letter and I wrote it over and forgot to say again about the saques. If you have it most done - don't try to change it - it si very pretty as it is. We find we cannot send by express so cheap as

Ask Eddie about those notes he gave me to settle with the old firm. What unclear (proofed? is there for unclear (payment?) We must try to get something to give for the ministry too soon. I will try to finish that for Mr. Hughes this week. How soon will they probably fill the butter tub?

How will it do for us to try to give $5 this year? 2 in your name 2 in mine and 1 in John Eddie's and let it be first [[pay'd?]  towards making J. Eddie a life member. Do you think we can get the money? If we cannot we must give unclear. Perhaps I can spare a little to send, if you need. Let me know what you do.

Dear Sisters and all, 
We have just written a letter to Lewis 
about Inthryn’s article which 
we inclose for you to read 
and hand to Lewis Sunday 
if you get this tomorrow night. 
Perhaps it will make it easier 
for him about not putting all those 
unkind criticisms in the Cenhadwr. It is too bad 
for Mr. Thomas to write such things. 
I wish we had known sooner 
of Gwesyn’s proposed trip - do you 
suppose he could do anything 
for us by collecting and getting 
names for the Cofiant?  I have 
written to ask Eddie but there 
has not time for me to get an-
swer. Rev. D. D. Davies was here the 
This is written up the left hand side of page and finishes at top margin:
and prices the 4ct one was pretty small.  Eddie writes that the roads [?] there are almost settled.  How is it with you?  We hope you will not have a long time with bad roads. We are glad the butter sold so well. What did David Lewis give for the final tub?  How are Wm and Sarah now? We are glad that John Eddie presses on and continues faithful to the meetings - I began to print

other evening and he said that 
he thought it would be well 
to ask Gwesyn or one of the 
other ministers to put the subject 
pf the Cofiant before our next 
Cymanfa and urge the friends 
to buy it.  What would you think 
of that?  If Gwesyn will do it, people 
would see that he is in sympathy 
with us in its publication.  Or would 
you rather ask someone else? 
We received the engravings all 
right - you do not say whether 
you think them fine enough. 
Bank note engraving  - or line en-
graving as it is called, is finer, 
but on account of the expense 
is not used so much for portraits 
That we were told costs $250 cutting for 
one portrait without printing any 
copies - we thought of having 
a 12 [?] book - about the size 
of this sheet - would you rather

have a larger portrait for this 
size page?  What would you think 
of having our bourgeois font sent 
here and I set the Cofiant?  
Do you think it practicable?  I 
would get a pretty cabinet stand and 
have it by the front window where 
Mary's table now is - Perhaps John 
Eddie will send postal cards to 
some firms in the city and learn 
the price of such stands - Mary 
has patients in the family of an 
expressman and she thinks she 
could get him to carry the type
to be printed &c.  There is no office 
near where we could have proofs taken 
I would have to do it with a soft 
plane - and you would need 
to be here, perhaps too, to read the 
proof.  My health is good so that I 
would not dread setting so much 
as I used to - would it be better for 
me to go home and set it there? 
Printing can be done nicely and 
cheaply here - the setting is the

most expense.  Of course, we 
must buy sorts if we do it here. 
How do you think just setting in bourgeois solid would look 
for the poetry? 
Mary has gone to College this p.m. 
She has promised to lecture once a 
week and this is her first day.  
She was hindered - and kept so 
constantly busy all this time that 
she had to go without preparing as 
she hoped to do.  I shall be very glad 
to see her safely through the task.  She 
had to leave patients for me to give 
electricity to them - as it was time 
for her to start.  She said Iorthryn ought 
to criticise her for taking too much on 
her hands!  We will try to send some 
oranges to you soon if not next week - will write when! 
Did they keep well?  Are the tomatoes all 
used?  We had some to dinner today and 
thought of you.  Mary took lunch with a 
friend last Sunday and had oysters fresh and 
[?] strawberries - we have had salad several 
times - we paid 4, 6, 8cts a head for it. 
I think we only bought three - at different times

433(?) W 34th New York
April 15, 1899 
My dear Sister 
Yours was received 
yesterday morning - also one from 
brother Eddie.  He seems to think 
best to delay the collecting tour 
and I sent him a card this a.m. 
saying that we would let it be so. 
We have had no time to think 
or consult for we have had a 
terrible accident here.  Yesterday 
morning about 11 Mrs Seixas - the 
mother in the family who tend 
Mary's door when she is out 
was fatally burned.  She was in 
the basement preparing dinner 
when her dress caught fire from 
the range.  She had on only 
a light thin calico wrapper
Iorthryn, so I wrote yesterday - I sent a card to dear Emlyn telling him of the accident which would delay our letter to him and the sending of the papers.  I wish he would write to [?] [?] Liverpool.  It is strange we have had nothing from him.  What would you think of a 12 [?] book with 240 pages I don't think we can sell enough copies not to lose by publishing

Her daughter hearing the scream-
ing ran down and seeing her 
mother enveloped in flames, 
turned quickly and came to 
find the Dr but she was 
so confused and histerical that 
we did not understand 
and as Mary on opening our door 
saw smoke coming from below 
she first ran to tuch the fire alarm 
and it was some minutes before 
any one found that Mrs Seixas 
was burning.  The fire was ex-
tinguished before Mary saw her. 
Nearly half the surface of the body 
was more or less burned under the chin but not on the face and 
head - the several on the front 
of the body and limbs.  Mary did 
all tat she possibly could and 
was with her all day and night till the last. Dr Wait 
also most of the time and Dr Sil-
ienthal came both yesterday and today They suc-
ceding in relieving the great 
Perhaps we had better enquire the cost of printing in Utien What would you think of my setting it with our type - J.E

pain and they had some hope this morning 
that she might recover, but the 
shock was too great.  She died at 
11 a.m. today just about 24 hours 
from the time of the accident. 
She had five children - four sons 
and one daughter - all here ex-
cept the eldest son who is in St 
Paul, Minn.  She had also a sister 
in law living with her and who 
was with her when her clothes 
took fire - but she fainted - It 
was altogether a very trying time 
two of the sons and the aunt 
were once at the same time in a dead 
faint and the daughter screaming with uncon-
trollable grief - Mary is 
very much worn and she is now sleeping.  She had been 
up nearly all the night before 
with another patient on the 
third floor of this house - a man 
almost delirious after drinking and

all day yesterday
when she could leave Mrs Seixas 
she had to go up to see the man. 
You will easily understand how utterly 
helpless we were.  Truly as one 
lady who called said - she often 
thought of that verse "In the midst 
of life we are in death."
We are gladdened by the good 
news of our dear John Eddie's new 
hope in Jesus.  How precious the 
thought that we are now all 
of us, as we hope, with our 
faces Zionward, pressing on 
to the high calling which is in 
Christ Jesus.  God help us that 
we may "[?] take our crown!" 
I had a precious letter from 
John this a.m. but Mary has not 
read it yet so I cannot send it with 
this - I will try to remember 
next time.  Mrs Jones thought it 
better for one of us to write to

New York, June 18, 1879
Dear Mother, Sisters
Mary wrote a card 
Saturday but I failed to write a letter 
as I expected.  Hope you have not been 
over anxious.  In Utica I called on 
cousin Alick before going up to 
cousin Mary's and gave him power 
to exchange our bonds as I wrote 
last, putting in the bank the 
balance - It will take almost 
all the July int. to make the exchange but what there will 
be he will put in the bank so 
I hope it will not emparrass mother. 
it nain Alick did not know of 
any better thing we could do in 
regard to it.

If you do set any kind of 
auricles for me, I think Rev J. J. Jones 
would lend you this money - if you 
haven't got enough yourself - till I 
could send it to you. I do not 
know indeed as you will think 
me wise in wishing you to 
get me any such things - use your 
own judgement and write to me 
anyway. When may we hope to 
see you home again? We are 
longing to see you once more.
We did not succeed in getting 
that vaccine to work - we tried 
it on Eddie the day after it was 
received - we fear we do not 
have skill enough to use it rightly. 
Mother wishes me to say in 
regard to Cynthia that she does 
not like to take anything unless 
you advise it.
Very aff. your sister
Jennie

seemed to her that Cynthia was
very much as she had seen
Nellie Roberts (Thomas now) at
times. She has got over them we 
believe - hers were hysterical - are
not Cynthia's also? What would
you advise us to do if she has
another when we can send for
a Dr? none but we unlearned
in physics have as yet seen her
at such times. Even if she took
no medicine from a doctor here
would he not be able better than
we to judge and note her symptoms?
Anna did not know what to
do - and we would not - any
of us know were we in her 
place. Please advise us.
Now, Mary, for my own request
- you know how hard it is for
me on account of my want of
hearing to get along with my
Sabbath school class. Do you know
- or could you find out about

something that I could wear at
that time to help. It does not
seem to me that it would injure
my hearing on the whole - perhaps
it would help me. If you can
get something and send with Eddie
I shall be so glad. I often think
I never shall be any better - I
hope I am thankful that I'm 
no worse. As to father I really
believe he could be very much
helped if not cured. You ask
Mrs. J.J. Jones again please, how
it was about that aged friend of
hers with whom she once went
to the infirmary, and who had
hardened wax in the ears. I 
have been talking to mother and
I believe she is quite inclined 
to make a trial. So if you
will but encourage them a
little I should not be surprised
if you saw them both before long.

You ought to see Carroll, he
walks all about I believe: he is a 
little timid with us yet and has 
kept pretty close to his father and
mother - John Eddie has just come
from school and they are getting
acquainted pretty fast. This is
John Eddie's first school day this summer and he
did not feel willing to lose the
first. Mate and Eddie brought
us a box of maple sugar - we 
has sent for some. But Eddie
will tell you all about it. We
wish you could be home to
enjoy our visit with Mate and
Carroll - we have enjoyed Eddie's
being with us today very much
he is at Lewis' now.
Daniel Jones is very sick - he
is not expected to live but a 
very short time now, Jane and
Lewis were there to see him yes-
terday.

what chance is there of that? Or, mother asks, had we better send to Ambler Bros?? I have forgotten Dr. Burdick's address and also the other so if you advise us to send--give the address also.
Lewis is quite poorly. Last week Thursday as he was trying to go from his office to dinner he fainted--but mother has written about it--yesterday he went to the office to work but was hardly able to do so. Fanny Ellis and mother went down to see him yesterday morning and Fanny drove on to the office and brought Lewis to the house to mother--he looks as though he had had a long sickness. Sunday he did not sit up but a very little. Mother walked up and down the steps

to his house. In the afternoon Rich W. Prichard and wife came here and mother went into the garden through the front door and from there to the orchard--after supper she went down cellar from out doors to the pork barrel. She felt very smart and walked without her cane--she does not use a crutch now. In the night she had a hard coughing spell and today has been feeling very poorly. So very very tired that she has had to lie down a great deal. I think she is some better this evening. Mary Anne and little Burtie were here to tea and tonight they have all, except mother, Franny and I, gone to church to hear Rev. E.R. Lewis lecture on the Centennial. Anna is feeling better some

Sept 22
today. Yesterday I had a letter from Mate? saying Edward was quite sick--the Dr feared at first that he was going to have typhoid fever, but when she wrote she said he hoped he had broken it up, and Edward had been able to eat a little that day--her letter was very short, we are hoping to hear again tomorrow.
We had a letter this PM from brother Butler. They are pretty well--just commencing a new term. We have been having very cold weather, but it has grown warm again and very pleasant--we have a nice lot of apples and a good many pears on that tree in the garden--but we have not got any peaches. I fear I shall regret it all the year if we do not get any, but I can

Caroline comes every week one or two days to help us so we get along better. We expect to get the Cenhadwr out this week and she has promised us two days. I think we will not wash this week--and the first day she comes instead of ironing she will make pies &c &c and then come our busy day. Lara will come then too if she is well and the roads permit.
Father sends $15 in this. I will send again to get some things. I want a dress very much if you could

think of something nice for me - and could tell something how much money I ought to send for it. You'll do so - perhaps you had and better send the box just get what does John Eddie think about getting a printing press? and who do you think? I want to know what I ought to let him have for my half of it. Jennie

(unknown) Jan. 13, 1881.
Dear Sister,
Your letter came last evening. The order from Columbus City which I sent to John Eddie came in one of your letters while we were in (unknown) you did and send the envelope only the letter and the order. Perhaps John Eddie will remember something about whether you preserved the envelopes of letter you received for me. I fear all my letters were not delivered to you and I would be glad if you would enquire at Station E. whether they have any record of any registered letters for me other than the one you got from Rev. G. Roberts, Big Rock, Ill, also ask there and of Postmaster James whether these are at their offices any letters of advice regarding orders I should

have. I am sorry to trouble you. I hope John Eddie can do what is necessary and so gave you. Did he get the order cashed finally? You do and say or whether you think Mr. James has any doubt about my identity. Those kid gloves I thought I left in your little bureau drawer I find are here hope you have not hunted much for them. When you send the box or package please do not put such a high valuation on it as to excite suspicion. We trust the papers will come safely in it as you are out of your room so much we hardly feel safe to have them there. We will probably be glad to have a box sent as freight by and by if we decide to have most of our things sent home. We do not know about your getting matting for those back rooms, it would not be so warm as a carpet. Sarah is willing you should put hers down of course she does not know so well as you mean to

use those rooms she says if it will make you anymore comfortable and you think best to do so, you had better use it. You would perhaps need to get something for lining as the carpet is not very heavy. We had good full letters from Edward and Mate last evening. M. was feeling better. E had taken a hard cold in the woods but was getting over it. Mate wrote in good spirits_the boys were in school. They are reading the Bible _ Carroll the whole, Charlie the Testament_ for reading they might have either a bible or a dollar. Charlie chose the last, Carroll the first. All of them have lately signed the temperance pledge at the M. E. Church where meetings are held every evening. Edward wrote when they were at breakfast that the next morning after they had signed Charlie slipped quietly from his chair in search of his pledge. When his mother asked him what he wanted he said, "I want to see if coffee is on it." "The meetings

are conducted by a Mr. Bundick, a talented, reformed, converted man," Eddie says. Mr. Hughes had a donation at (unknown) last night. I went with Bobbie and Libbie Lewis and Jane and Maggie were there. There were a good many there especially young people. I saw and spoke with Fred Owens and Jennie. A good many young married couples gave the brightness of there presence to the occasion. Fremont & Lydia, Johnny Davies and Maggie Thomas. Mary Price and her husband, Katy Parry and hers. Anna has such a cold that she did not dare to go. She has quite a sore throat which is much worse nights. She coughs some and is hoarse. Sarah says the throat looks red and inflamed. My finger joints begin to trouble me a little - wish I had some of my med, Dr. Syl, advised for it. With much love from all to you both - Jennie Everett. P.S. We have a great deal of snow now but the roads are pretty good. When have you heard from John? J.E.

(unknown), March 28, 1881.
Dear Sister, Louisa Griffith reached home Friday, I think. Maggie also came home from (unknown) the same day and rode w with Mr. G. from the village _ they drove over here to bring the things that you sent. We are much obliged to you and J. E. for taking trouble to get them. We ought to sendyou money to pay for these and things that you got for us before _ please let us know how much. Will it trouble you very much to send me some more med. such as Dr. Lif gave me for my head. I feel the trouble when I get tired or worried _ my right arm give me a little uneasiness. It gets to sleep morning and I have to shake it a good deal before it feels right, _ and when I rake the fire _ i.e. draw the pokes over the bars of the grate _ my arm and hand seem to prick.

all over _ so it is when I write. I do not know but it is the same nervous affection that I feel in my head. The pricking feeling begins in my hand and runs up my arm. I seem to need to be out doors a great deal and now lately I have been more in doors. Sarah continues quite feeble. Her cough seemed better night before last she coughed very much and a good deal last night. The weather is cold, with such a strong wind that it is hard to keep the house warm. Anna complains of feeling very weak. She does not venture to go from home for fear of taking cold. I shall be very glad when they can go a little. We are anxious about you. Please let us know how you are. We are very glad John Eddie is so much help and comfort to you. We hope you will do each other all the good you can. What will you do next summer? Wish one of us could be with you but I cannot see how that can be.

I am writing to Eddie this morning. We had a letter from him Friday evening. He intended to give this week to arranging his affairs - shipping his lumber, fixing his side = walk  unclear, so that he can leave home and take unclear our book?. I am sending him the ship which you wrote about Miss Jones and the prophet? in Nelsons. I do [[unclear he will have some measure of success for us. ~ We are expecting Mate will come with him and make us a little visit. She does not like to unclear with us as she unclear it does not agree with her here, - Do you think it  posible? that there can be any unclear in our

atmosphere.  We have not 
had our cellar cleaned 
yet.  I do not feel strong 
enough to undertake it 
and I do not know how 
it was done last year 
or whether we ought to do 
it or not.  The windows 
are open of course .
We heard from cousin 
Lizzie from Remsen last 
week - She would be ready 
to visit us about two weeks 
she thought if convenient to 
us  - & we shall probably have  
her here soon.  We want cousin 
Mary to come and Lizzie may 
stay with Fannie while 
she comes.  I must write to 
them.  We hope you will write 
soon and often.  Give love to Mrs 
Jones, Lizzie Thomas & mother &c. 
I believe I long for New York 
and the many dear friends there.

Just before tea Anna went out 
again round the house to the 
lilac bush by the bedroom window 
and brought in a branch to blossom in water in the house.  A little 
branch that she has had in 
now several days is opening its buds finally.  You ought to see it.  
She has also some nice tomato 
plants in cans and some in the 
flowerpot not yet transplanted - these 
with the geranium slips &c make 
a fine house garden. - Anna 
feels better for her out yesterday. 
I washed and got the clothes dried 
nicely.  Today is windy and chilly 
again.  I fear my last letter 
to you may make you uneasy 
about me.  I am feeling better 
than I was then  - I would be glad 
to get the med, tho'.
Monday was cold with a strong

west wind.  I was anxious to go 
to the village and so about 4 p.m. 
I started on the [?].  Went down 
easily enough but had quite a tustle 
with the wind coming home.  I 
called at Hugh Thomas' to see 
Sarah.  She fell down stairs at 
Amelia's some time in the winter. 
Her shoulder twisted [?] but the Utica Dr did not think it seriously hurt and she 
did not get along.  About two weeks 
ago she came home.  Dr Williams 
found the bone broken and set it. 
It does not join however - and 
he fears he will be obliged to cut 
the ends of the bones before they 
will join - he is going to wait an-
other week.  They told her what 
he says and she, of course, worries 
a great deal and feels quite dis=
courage.  Dr Williams is going 
to keep a drug store in the village 
- he has been building near Wm.

Tomas' shop expects to open 
the 1st of April and then he 
says he will not go out practicing 
any more. - Robbie is going to 
the village this morning and 
Anna is getting ready to go with 
him - she will try to see the Dr 
and get him to come to see Sarah 
once more, if he will. - Robbie is 
intending to visit his brother 
Owen to attend his wedding.  R expects to start next 
Friday and he says if it will 
not cost much more he thinks 
he will come back through New 
York, so that he may see you. 
He will probably write to you 
from Wilmington.  Libbie and the 
baby are well - baby groes more 
and more interesting - wish you 
could see him.  There is an 
examination of teachers in the 
village this week.  Libbie's brother

Jennie wants you not to worry about her. she is better than when she wrote before. She has that numbness in her hand yet, but not as bad. She thinks the medicine she needs is what she got first of Dr. Lil. she does not want you to trouble about it. now as you are feeling so poorly and she is better. Cousin Mary said she thought Jennie seemed better that at any time since Mother's death. Caroline says she thinks J. is gaining every day - don't you thinks she is in danger of getting vain with so many compliments?
Remsen, April 6, 1881
Dear Sister and Nephew,
It is hard to 
know what to write about John Eddie's 
getting a school to teach this next summer. 
He had better speak to Robbie when he 
sees him as they (he & his mother), are coming home 
through New York. Robbie knows more about 
schools and wages than we do. John D. 
told me that George has had a 
letter from you. I asked him whether he 
thought would get schools for you, and 
he said he did not know. George 
could not tell - he did not know 
how many would be wanting schools, 
nor how many of the schools had been 
taken. John D. said he supprised that 
George would feel that he ought first 
to supply those with schools who had 
passed the (his) examination which he had

I am some better than when I was last week. Don't worry about us, but take good care of yourselves. 
last week in the village, if there 
should be more schools than teachers 
in his district, he might give you a school. 
We have enquired some and find that 
it is rather late. The schools have many 
of them been taken. The Green District School 
was taken before Louisa came home. 
She intended to apply for that; now 
we understand she does not intend to 
teach. It will and be very bad if John 
Eddie does not get a school, tho we 
would rather not have him disappointed, 
He could then finish his school year 
nicely and be ready for next year. 
Perhaps he will be in the same 
school another year, we cannot 
tell, he probably will be in some school 
if his health is spared. and it may 
be a great advantage to him to have 
passed the examinations there. Then 
when vacation comes there will be 
work enough. There are a great

many things we shall need to have 
done + we would gladly pay him wages 
so that he can be earning. One thing, 
we did engage to have 20 cords 
of stove wood saved in our woods for 
our use next winter. Griffith Jones 
was to do it. if he does not do it now 
perhaps he will early in the summer. 
We shall have to get it split and 
that J. E. could do. 
I am writing this in great haste 
as we have just learned that Theodore 
is going to the village, Sarah contin-
ues quite feeble tho' we think she 
is gaining some. She took a little fresh cold 
yesterday which aggravates her cough. 
She thinks the cod liver oil is helping 
her. We are sorry Mary feels so poorly. 
hope she will take care and not 
overdo. S. thinks you had better take some cod liver oil. 
We got her letter today and J. E.'s Monday. 
We are having some cold stormy

weather with more snow and 
high winds. The roads are not 
good for wagons or sleighs. in some 
places the sleighing is good, in others 
the ground is bare. Lewis was here 
today. he went to the village in his 
cutter, and he got a letter from Jane 
dated Phil. There was one yesterday 
from Robbie to Libbie. You will 
probably see them before you 
get this letter. Anna has some 
sore throat again, better today. She took a little 
cold too yesterday. She has some 
plums in blossom of which we 
will inclose a little for you. 
She has quite a garden in the 
house. Write soon and often 
as you can. How are you getting 
along housekeeping? If you can, 
please send with Robbie a couple 
of large boxes of sardines. 
Love from Jennie & the rest.

Remsen, April 16, 1881
Dear Sister and Nephew,
We have been rather negligent about writing to you the last week, I am sorry to say. I have been trying to get the class letter on the way and that has hindered me somewhat in writing other things. Will Mary please send her report or shall I get along without anything especial from her? I have written three times now to Mary Daniels Smith without receiving any reply. Can you find the name of her husband, also that of Lizzie Breed's, and send them to me? I have looked a great deal for my copy of the last unclearunclear, but can find it nowhere. It would be a help if I had it, tho' perhaps I can get along without. Does John Eddie know anything where it is? That trunk came all right. most of our things I think I left in a box. I was so poorly when I came home that I did not

arrange the things snug as I ought. I would rather not have Jane seen the trunk and things in the condition they were but never mind. She took it home first because as Robbie said he could not very well bring it in the buggy. and then they brought it up from there the next day. Robbie said we were to have half of the bananas and so the girls divided them with Libbie and the candy also. there were only two oranges which Jane said were one for Anna and one for Sarah. The box of ambrosia we also have, but we do not what to do with it. we think from the picture that it is intended for a drink. Jane says they have a box too and they are quite as much at a loss as we. please enlighten us. The Easter egg is very pretty and Sarah sends thanks for it. You need not trouble about sardines I got a box in the village Thursday last. They keep them in the new store where G.W.R. was to be, small box 11 cents. I also got a can of tomatoes 13 cents, five apple, 28 cents and peaches 25 cents so you see

Remsen is quite a place. We sent with Mr. John Williams to Utica for oranges and fresh beef - we have sent with him three times now. the last time-Wednesday- he brought us 4 dozen oranges 35 cents per dozen and 6 1/2 lbs of beef at 14 cents 93 cents for the unclear-his charges for bringing & getting was 20 cents, making his bill $2.53. The time before he got 2 dozen oranges and about the same amount as this of beef and his bill including charges was only $1.75, so oranges are a trifle higher. They are like those you sent in the box, very nice and the girls eat two or three every day. We got fresh eggs and have them once and sometimes unclear and milk the girls normally take a lunch of warm bread and milk just before retiring. We have some nice veal now-we got 4 lbs of Robbie a few days ago, when he butchered, and yesterday we baked a piece. We have beef twice a day baked or fried and nice potatoes sometimes onions, baked apples & unclear. Our unclear sweets are not quite gone yet. I forgot to mention the smoked beef & pickled peaches. Mr. W.  got a week ago box us unclear Mary send the unclear beef & peaches very  unclear Wont you come and board with us? We are very glad you

have made such good use of those 
canned goodies - wish there had been as many again 
and there would have been I think had I been 
feeling well - I wish I had not come home just 
as I did, learning so many things that I wanted 
to get and to do, but it was perhaps best so. 
My visit about Utica did me much good and 
I have been usually well ever since.  That and Mary 
sent in her last I took three doses and am resting
as she directed.  I do not feel any effect from it yet. 
Thursday I went to the village to get the things 
from Utica.  Robbie has a hired boy Theodore Williams 
and they were busy chopping in the woods - so 
I went in the buggy alone.  I had a pretty
rough ride, as the snow is still 
pretty deep in some places - I must 
tell about it again  - Now R is ready 
to start.  Sarah seems a little better 
- Anna also - With love
Jennie Everett
What has J.E. done about a school?

Remsen June 7, 1881
Dear Sister 
This must be a short letter 
as I fear I may not have time to write 
much and I know you must be longing 
for a home letter.  I did not know 
anything about your cutting your hand 
till we got your last letter and we 
feel very much troubled about it.  So much 
pain and difficulty in using it must 
wear upon you sadly especially as you 
are all alone and far from well.  How 
glad we would be if only we could do some-
thing for you!  It almost seems that it 
would be better for you to go to Mrs. Twombly's 
or somewhere else and board.  
You ought not to have any care outside 
of your practice and you need to be 
so that you can have your meals reg=
ularly and other attentions that you 
cannot give to yourself.  If your health 
gets better, you can do so much more

you know!  But I do not dare to advise.  
I cannot find times to weigh the pros 
and cons.  It certainly must be very hard 
for you to be paying so much but without 
really having the good of so much room 
because it is not furnished and cared 
for.  I should dearly love to see you 
but must try to trust that God is leading 
us, tho' it is in a way full of darkness 
and uncertainty.  It has seemed that 
Sarah is a little better these last days.  
For three days now it has been too cold for 
her to ride - yesterday she walked out 
a little way into the yard.  This afternoon 
Mr W Thomas and his wife called to see her.  
Sarah enjoyed seeing them.  They had 
not been able to come before.  Sarah 
got some tired of course but rested 
afterwards.  She still suffers with neuralgia 
tho' not so much as before.  
Robbie starts I must stop.
Love
Jennie

here ever so much and it seems lonely 
without them.  John Eddie and Robbie went 
to the caucus at 'Squire Lewis' last night.  The 
candidates were out in full force and 
carried everything before them.. This after=
noon the boys went together to a raising of a 
new drive house at J.R Griffiths' and 
Robbie came home in time to milk 
and left John Eddie visiting I believe 
at Gth. Griffiths'.  He came home as I was 
writing and Janes father with him.  Timothy 
stayed out with the horses for a few minutes 
then J Eddie went with them to the 
village.  There is to be a caucus there 
tonight and our boy wanted to see how 
they progress.  It is a great comfort to 
have his company and help.  He is 
studying Greek & Latin and expects to 
have his final recitation with Prof. Evans 
next Tuesday evening.  He is looking well 
and of good cheer.  We hope it will be no 
great loss to him not to go from home

just now.  Wish he could have a leave of 
absence from Pres. Webb.  He wrote a request to him for it and sent it with [?] so we hope he will get it.  It is hard for us 
to decide, or know what the winter will bring us.  
Dr Wms was here yesterday and he told 
Anna that he thought Sarah 
would be strong enough to go before the cold 
weather sets in.  he asked if we had thought 
of anywhere in particular and told him that 
you suggested Dunellan - he was pleased 
as he wished Sarah to have the benefit 
of some sea breeze.  He thinks Sarah is 
doing well now if only she could eat 
more.  Her appetite has been poorer than usual 
the last two weeks - Dr is now giving her a 
preparation of beef, iron and wine, besides the 
wheat phosphates, oil and cough drops.  Today 
she took two rides, but yesterday and day 
before she went but once, as there was a 
strong cold wind.  Today has been very pleasant. 
We have been looking a good deal for 
your letter written after you visited 
Dunellan - we hope to find it yet, for we

Remsen? Oct. 11, 1881
Dear Sister
Your letter received Sat. eve. We do not think that it would be practicable for us to stop with you, tho' we thank you all the same. Sarah would not be able to go up and down stairs as you propose. She is weaker by far than you seem to think, and it looks doubtful to us about her being able to endure the fatigue of the journey unless she had a very quiet resting place afterwards. Do you still think Dunellen a favorable place for her. She was almost discouraged because you write that Mrs. Jones and Mrs. Thomas think it will be too cold there. Dr. was here yesterday and Sarah seemed quite bright and cheery then--he spoke encour

encouragingly. S. had taken some cold those frosty cold nights of last week and suffered with her side again but that was so much better that Dr. did not do anything for it. Last night was frosty again and she is worse again--coughs a good deal more. The sun is clear this morning and she is going for a ride. Dr. insists a great deal upon her getting out all she can. Sometimes we are greatly discouraged--the cold weather is coming so early and her strength is so small--there has been really no length of warm weather for her to gain in tho' we have had warm days--there have been almost as many cold. If everything could be arranged so that there would be no trouble in New York or at Dunnellen do you think it possible to have it so? How I wish you were not so confined by your business or that I could

go to see to have everything arranged. Perhaps Eddie will come home through N.Y. and do it for us. I think sometimes I will write to Tommy Thomas and see what he says about houses and rents. Do you think he could help us? What would you say to our staying here? Fitting up the parlor with a coal stove for the girls? I have no time to think but must write fast as I can just what comes to mind. Anna has teeth ache and a swollen face--has been most sick but is better.
Love to Mrs. Jones and Mrs. Thomas and ever so much to our Dr. Sister.
Jennie

Remsen, Oct. 14, 1881
My dear Sister.
I believe Jennie wrote you last week that S. had taken some cold. It seemed to affect her head then--she had cold in the head, with diarrhea, but was better of that till Monday evening, when she had a slight chill, or chilly feeling, and could hardly keep her teeth from chattering. We got her warm very soon, and thought her no worse Tues. eve--she had similar chills at about the same time but not very severe. She has not felt as well since--has been quite feeble and suffered from great oppression in the chest and hoarseness. I can hardly tell whether this last is from the throat or tightness in the chest. She has had

a little sore throat now and then for several days. Uncle Henry and Hattie came here Wednesday, and unclear all night, and we thought the trouble in her chest was partly (at least0 from over exertion talking louder than usual with him. I went to see the Dr. yesterday, and told as well as I could how she was. He said he was afraid there was some pneumonia and told us to apply mustard to her chest. He will come to see her today, and after that I will write you again. I told him I hoped this would not prove very serious--he looked very sober and said, "Yes I hope so, but circumscribed pneumonia is not a pleasant thing to have in connection with tuberculosis." I think she is not any worse today than yesterday, but

is pretty feeble. The mustard relieved her some, but she was not able to keep it on long, as it made her so nervous. We have put on another this morning, as the skin was not reddened after last night. She had a little stitch in her left side last evening, which was relieved with mustard and Aconide? and Brg. This pains her some today still, but is a good deal better. We are very grateful to you for kindly offering to take us all in, if we should come to N.Y. but are afraid there would be no quiet resting place, with boarders and children, patients and all. I do not think she has been able yet to take the journey but cannot tell of course how it will be. Wish we could consult with you but of course our anxiety now is to have her relieved of this cold. We feel very anxious, but try to

hope for the best.
Anna has written so far and I have just been reading it over. The swelling in A's face is about gone and her teeth are not so sore or painful. Neither she nor Sarah have much appetite. Robbie brought S. a nice fat partridge night before last. We roasted it yesterday. It is very nice and tender and they enjoy it as much as they enjoy eating anything. We have been having cold drizzly weather but today is clear after a hard frost last night we have not got the apples all in and a good many of them are injured by frost so that they can not be kept--we intend having cider made for vinegar from part. I am going to the village this morning to see for a stove to put in the parlor and I must get ready--Jennie and Anna 
With Love.

Remsen, Dec. 19, 1881
My dear Sister,
We got the bird &c. Friday in time for Sarah's dinner and she enjoyed it greatly. The oyster stuffing was very nice but it was too rich or something for her, so we took it out and feasted on it ourselves. We thank Mrs. Van Buren very much for her kindness in cooking it and the first birds too for us. I do not know how to thank her enough but you must do it for us. We were highly entertained with your rhyming letter. You quite surprised yourself that time. Try again, please! I fully intended writing so that you might have a letter Saturday night but someway failed to do so. Dr. was here Sat. morning--he said the main thing now is for us to give Sarah all the nourishment possible. Anna asked him if he could suggest 
the memoir unclear shorter. What would you have? I was thinking this morning that it would not be a bad plan to have a little word from us as a family to father's old friends. I do not no exactly what but thanking unclear past and asking their hearty support in the future for Mr. Davies in his endeavor to continue the Cenhadwr both for the sake of the cause itself and because there can be no truer better or more lasting monument to father's memory than a large circulation of his magazine. What can you

anything more than he had done. HE said no! Ana asked if we ought to urge her to eat--he said not if we thought she was taking all her stomach would bear. Anna said that she feared Sarah was losing ground--yes, he replied, she is, gradually. He told John Eddie that if she was not able to take some more nourishment he did not think she could live till spring. We try to do what we can, and if you can help us in any way, please do, that's a dear sister. If you send a bird or anything again we think it would be better not to cook it but to freeze it and then we could cook when she felt like eating it. The cranberries you sent unfortunately tasted of the box--it would be better to send such things for us to cook. The grapes were very nice and acceptable. Cousin Hattie Roberts came on the noon train Saturday with her friend David Williams. She brought a quart of very nice oysters a couple of sweet oranges, a bunch of two of 
write if you approve the idea please write something and I will do the same. Did we tell you that Mr. D. had bought that font? HE paid us $50 for it--not quite what we expected but the best perhaps we could do. When he paid I offered payment for our

white grapes, some celery--also a can of peaches and bottle of vinegar from cousin Mary. Anna had written telling Mary that Sarah was longing for pickled peaches and asking her if there were any to be had. Mary sent these because she did not have or find any pickled. She thought if we put hot spiced vinegar on these they might answer. We have taken half of the can to try. Sarah enjoyed what Hattie brought. She and Anna had broiled oysters to supper Sat.--we all had some soup for Sunday breakfast and Sarah had raw oysters Sunday to supper. We had company to supper Sat. and Sunday; Mr. and Mrs. Wm. Prichard, Sat. the first time she had been out with her baby now five weeks old Sunday. Owen D. Griffith called and took tea with us. We baked the goose Sat. for dinner. Sarah said it was nice and seemed to relish it. This noon we had some of it cold and Sarah called for some of the bones to pick. After dinner she told 
number next year but he would not take anything. He said he meant to send us the Cen. as long as we would like to have it. It is very pleasant to have him feel so. Anna is going with J.E. to the village with this before supper.

Anna that she did not believe that the goose had ever enjoyed a dinner so much as she had picking his bones. 
We are having a very mild winter so far. There is scarcely a bit of snow to be seen any where. We shall have to cook our turkey pretty soon if the weather does not grow colder. We made a few sausages the last of the week--had some of them to dinner Sunday--all said they were good.
I am enclosing a letter we have just had from Hattie, that you may read it and answer her questions about oculists. Please return the letter because it is Sarah's. Did you read that last article in the last Cen. signed by Jane? What do you think of it? What do you suppose she means by asking to have all the "old debt" sent to her? Can you advise us what we had better have on the next Cen. cover. There should be something about the debt before [[1899?] and we would like
and as it is 4 p.m. I have not much more time to write. Much, much love from us four. Write often and do not wait for us. Your aff. sister J. Everett.

Turin?, March 29, 1882.
Dear Sister,
We are glad to get even a few words from you, but hope it will not be long before you can find time to write more fully. We are sorry that you are feeling so unsettled and we sympathize with you in your feeling of loneliness. Wish John Eddie might have gone to be with you but we did not feel like urging it much, against his judgement. He thought it would be wasting time for him to be going over the same ground as when he was there last, and we hope we have done right. We had a letter from him Saturday night. He had a comfortable, pleasant journey and reached Mexico about 3 p.m. Thursday and got nicely settled before night. He went through Syracuse as he did not

start early enough from Utica to reach Rome in season to get the Northern train for Mexico. He will perhaps write to you so I will not forestall.
Thursday P.M. I send this that you may see that I did try to write to you before, tho' there is not much in it. As it nears the last of the month we are wishing to know whether you have decided to move. I wish I might be with you to help for it--will be hard for you alone. How will it be if Mrs. Van Buren leaves and you stay. Must you be responsible for the rent of the whole flat? How is your health now? We shall be very glad to hear particularly--cards are good but they cannot quite take the place of letters. We have had two good full letters from John Eddie. He takes no studies now except Greek and Latin and writing. The classes are in advance of him but he hopes by application to keep up. They begin Virgil and Anabasis. His letter was written Monday, so he had not had much chance to tell. He attended Methodist church Sunday

morning with his roommate and in the evening went with Johnny to the Presbyterian church. 
The weather has been very variable this week. Sunday snowy, a soft wet snow which turned to rain. Anna and Mate? did not go out. E. and I went in the morning and the boys. They and their father went to Sunday school but I only went to the preaching service. Coming home Mrs. Hughes gave me the shelter of her umbrella as it was raining. Monday it rained hard all day--a warm rain from the south. The wind changed at night and Tuesday was exceeding cold with a sharp north wind. Anna and I went in the afternoon to the funeral of Mrs. Lyman's sister. Her body was brought from Forestville to be buried in the cemetery here by her husband. Services were at Mrs. L's. Yesterday was much warmer. We washed, and in the afternoon I went with Mrs. White to the Methodist church to the funeral of Mr. Hart's brother. Anna and Mate? went for a walk before tea and just before

going to bed I went up to the store for a walk. It was mild and pleasant but during the night there was quite a rainfall. Today there has been a strong cold wind with occasional flurries of fine snow. I went for a walk to the cemetery and back. The sidewalks are clear and dry, but the roads muddy.
I have just thought since beginning to write whether it would be much help for you if you move for me to go down a little while to help you. Anna would not miss me so much while she is here. My health is good and everybody remarks upon my looking so well. I was weighed last night--121 lbs. It is time for mail and I must close, but I must say we are having a great treat this maple sugar season.--have had some and made Jack wax and warm sugar several times. Adieu with love from all. Jennie Everett.

Remsen, Oct. 13, 1882
My dear Sister,
Your letter has not been followed by another fuller one according to promise. We fear you are not feeling well--wish very much we could have you with us. We have had quite a fright and all because we were too confiding and trustful in a stranger. Last Tuesday just as we were getting ready to sit down to tea a gentleman called and said his name was Everett and he thought perhaps he might find relatives here. We told him we thought he was mistaken. He said his father came from North Wales and 
Anna has much trouble with her head all the time. She finds it tires her a good deal to ride. Still it is better than staying home all this time. She enjoys going if she does get tired. She was most decided not to go to Utica--Mate? would want to come back the same day or the next and A. fears it would be too hard for her. Please write soon. Much love to you and other friends--Mrs. Jones, Thomas, Askin? &c. -J.E.

address--cousin Robert's, John's and I don't know but some others of our relatives. He said his aged mother was very anxious to know something of his gather's relatives. His father had been dead many hears, We can see now that we were very green!
We are a little nervous nights and it does not seem pleasant to think of staying here so much alone. We do not know of any one who wants to rent and we do not fancy living here with another family. Would you care about trying to keep the place in the family? If you could be home awhile it seems that we could look over things and dispose of what we would not want to take to make a home elsewhere. We had a letter from John Eddie about the time we got yours. He asked how soon he had better come

cousin Robert's family and asked whether he was cousin Thomas' son. He said his father's name was Thomas--then I remembered I should have said cousin Robert. He replied that his brother's name was Robert. Well Anna came and talked with him and I invited him to supper with us, and afterwards as it grew late we invited to stay all night. We had no where to put him but in ma's bed room. I remembered that my purse with $13 was in the drawer and I put it in my packed and took it up stairs thinking of the petition "lead us not into temptation." I thought Anna's was up stairs but I did not ask her. We did not get up very early the next morning and he did not come from the room till we were just ready for breakfast at eight. He said he was going to Western to find his mother's

relatives. He had been to the Adriandae's? for his health &c. &c. After he left us Mate was going with Robbie to the village. Anna went to her purse to get some money to send for something. There should have been unclear and a little change there. He had taken all but a few cents change--also some from the drawer of the missionary collection. We do not know exactly how much. It was the Feb. unclear and we had never opened it. He left 38 its probably took .50 or .75. We do not know whether he took anything else. The box with papers was in that large trunk in the recess--we think he did not look there but my fur gloves which I kept in the lower drawer we found under the wash stand. The week before there were some burglaries committed in the village. We did not know what to do and so did nothing about following him. Anna gave him Aunt Hughe?

What do you suppose it would cost?
Our garden has been doing very well--our potatoes hold out well and are excellent. The boys hoed them before their father started and they have hoed more or less in the garden since. The celery looks nicely--they have hoed that twice with Anna's help.
Thomas Evans was hurt badly the other day. The horse ran away with and threw him out breaking some of his ribs and cutting his head. We drove into Fremont's years to enquire. Lydia was with her father. F. could not tell--I suppose they did not know jus that his injuries are.
We are well--are going to the village this morning and so must hasten to close.

Glyn? 11 a.m. Nov. 9, 1882
Dear Sister,
A. rested well last night and thinks she feels stronger today than she has at all since that Wednesday. We got your letter yesterday and were very glad. Jane was here last evening--also R. & L. This is a mild and very pleasant day. Mr. & Mrs. P. wish to be remembered to you. unclear Evan and family were here this p.m. They will not probably take this place as it is not so large as they want. A. enjoyed the visit with them. She came to table both to dinner & tea. She is now in the sitting room. Mr. & Mrs. Wm Thomas are there. I am finishing this to send with them. We

Unclear, March 29, 1898
My dear Sister, 
We have two letters from you now unanswered. I can not tell just now what will be best about the cofiant??.- Perhaps we had better wait a little and see what Lewis intends to do. You know you requested Wm Thomas to speak to him. _ We must decide soon what to publish in the next number about our dear mother,s death this time it will be only a short notice supposing you write something and we do the same, and perhaps John will and Lewis can make something out of what we all write to publish-or can you suggest a better way?
